module.description:
The lsxcommand LoadModule is a text box that sits on your desktop. It will let you type !bangs, folder names, documents, apps, urls, etc and execute them. Think of it as a very customizable address bar :)
if you specify a border width and you dont have CommandNotMoveable set, you can drag it around by the border. there is a problem that some people are having where the mouse cursor is not set back to a normal cursor after it is off the text box. to fix this, use CommandNoCursorChange to stop lsxcommand from changing the cursor.
just a tip: lots of programs names work in lsxcommand.. you can type stuff like 'notepad', 'icq', 'netscape', to start some programs instead of the full path. the history is working great.
Note: Not all the text docs are in the html docs. All of the step.rc and bang commands are, but not all explanations. If you want to read more about the calculator, time, transparency, ... check lsxcommand.txt.

command.name: CommandX
command.description: x position on the screen.

command.name: CommandY
command.description: y position on the screen.

command.name: CommandWidth
command.description: width in pixels.

command.name: CommandHeight
command.description: height in pixels.

module.command: overides the default of being Always On Top of other windows.

command.name: CommandHiddenOnStart
command.description: start hidden

command.name: CommandOffsetX
command.description:
This value determines which point on the screen LSXCommand should use as a reference for the CommandX value.
0: left - 1: horizontal center 2: right

command.name: CommandOffsetY
command.description:
This value determines which point on the screen LSXCommand should use as a reference for the CommandY value.
0: top - 1: horizontal center - 2: bottom

command.name: CommandBevelBorder
command.description: Use bevels instead of borders.

command.name: CommandWaitForBox
command.description:
LsxCommand will not appear until he is loaded in a box with the !CommandBoxHook.
Please check lsbox documentation.

command.name: CommandBorderSize
command.description:
Width in pixels of the border.
If you want to have different sized borders on each side, use CommandTopBorderSize, CommandBottomBorderSize, CommandLeftBorderSize, and CommandRightBorderSize.

command.name: CommandBottomBorderSize
command.description: Height in pixels of the bottom border, overrides $CommandBorderSize$ for that border.

command.name: CommandTopBorderSize
command.description: Height in pixels of the top border, overrides $CommandBorderSize$ for that border.

command.name: CommandLeftBorderSize
command.description: Width in pixels of the left border, overrides $CommandBorderSize$ for that border.

command.name: CommandRightBorderSize
command.description: Width in pixels of the right border, overrides $CommandBorderSize$ for that border.

command.name: CommandTextSize
command.description: pixel size of the text

command.name: CommandTextBold
command.description: Is the text going to be bold.

command.name: CommandTextUnderline
command.description: Is the text going to be underlined.

command.name: CommandTextItalic
command.description: Is the text going to be italic.

command.name: CommandBGColor
command.description: background color

command.name: CommandBackground
command.description:
Path to your background image. If this is not an absolute path, LSXCommand looks in your images directory.
Note: If this option is not specified, the background and border colors are used.

command.name: CommandStretchBackground
command.description: If set to true, the background image will be stretched.

command.name: CommandTransparentEditBox
command.description:
Makes the area in which you type transparent to the background. If this option is not specified, the background image shows through.
If there is no background, the background color is used.

command.name: CommandTextColor
command.description: text color

command.name: CommandBorderColor
command.description: color of the border

command.name: CommandTextFontFace
command.description: font for the text

command.name: CommandNotMoveable
command.description: if this is set you will not be able to drag it around by the border

command.name: CommandNoCursorChange
command.description: does not change mouse cursor when over the text box

command.name: CommandAssumeNetAddress
command.description: If a command just doesn't cut it, you can have it start your browser with the address.

command.name: CommandExplorePaths
command.description: If enabled, any directory path you enter into LSXCommand will open a treed explorer window, instead of the standard folder window.

command.name: CommandHistoryFile
command.description: Specifies the file lsxcommand stores its history in.

command.name: CommandHistoryEntries
command.description: Sets number of history entries of which to keep track. Note: I haven't really stress-tested LSXCommand, so I don't know how well it scales up, but it shouldn't be too taxing even at somewhere around 50 entries. But I think that's a bit much anyway...

command.name: CommandHistoryMenuEntries
command.description: Sets the maximum number of history entries available from the context menu.

command.name: CommandClearHistoryOnStartup
command.description:
Clears the history on startup.
Note: You *will* lose the history in $CommandHistoryFile$ - not only the history in memory.

command.name: CommandNewestHistoryItemsOnTop
command.description: This setting places newer history items at the top of the menu, instead of at the bottom.

command.name: CommandUnixHistory
command.description: The most popular UNIX shell (bash) has the inverse history navigation: Up for previous, down for next. You can use this system with this setting.

command.name: CommandAddExternalsToHistory
command.description: If this is on, LSXCommand will add any commands launched with the !Command !Bang command to the history. Since I've been using AlterScript with this a lot, it became annoying to have all of AlterScript's commands end up in LSXCommand's history.

command.name: CommandContextMenuStandardItems
command.description:
This item does two things. It first turns on the standard menu items: Cut, Copy and Paste. Second, it tells where to put the standard items, above or below the LSXCommand specific menus.
Example:
CommandContextMenuStandardItems 1 ; Above
CommandContextMenuStandardItems 2 ; Below
CommandContextMenuStandardItems 0 ; Off (Default)

command.name: CommandContextMenuAboveBox
command.description: If you have your LSXCommand window at the bottom of the screen, you will want to turn this on. If at the top, leave this off. This sets where the context menu will appear - above or below the LSXCommand box.

command.name: CommandContextMenuExecute
command.description:
Tells LSXCommand to execute a selection from the context menu instead of copying its data to the LSXCommand box.
Note: Since the point of search engines is to have you enter a search phrase, it is not possible to have search engines execute.

command.name: CommandContextMenuOrder
command.description:
Specifies which order each submenu should appear.
For instance, you can have History, Alias, then Search Engines or Alias, History, Search Engines, or...
The setting is 3 numbers: 0, 1, and 2. The combination of these numbers sets in which order each submenu appears. The first number is the position of the History submenu. The second is the Alias submenu. And the last is the Search Engines submenu.

command.name: CommandContextMenuAutoPopup
command.description: If you set this to true, then everytime the mouse will come over the lsxcommand box, the contect menu will appear.

command.name: CommandNoWarnOnError
command.description: If there is an error (for instance, if the command you entered is invalid or the calculator couldn't evaluate the expression you entered), you will get an error message. This, when turned on, will suppress it.

command.name: CommandHideOnCommand
command.description: Hides lsxcommand when a command is issued.

command.name: CommandSelectAllOnFocus
command.description: Selects everything in the command box on focus.

command.name: CommandSelectAllOnMouseFocus
command.description:
Just like CommandSelectAllOnFocus, just that it only works when clicking to focus LSXCommand.
The reason these are two separate options is for people like me: I like to be able to just click once to put the cursor where I want it -not select the entire command. But, some people like the explorer way of doing things better, so I added it.

command.name: CommandHideOnUnfocus
command.description: Hides LSXCommand when it loses keyboard focus. This can be used to hide LSXCommand after it runs an app.

command.name: CommandNoClearOnCommand
command.description: wont clear the input after you hit enter

command.name: CommandClearOnHide
command.description: clear the text when mod is hidden

command.name: CommandOnFocus
command.description: Will execute a command when you !FocusCommand (or when you focus it with the mouse).

command.name: CommandOnUnfocus
command.description: Will execute a command when you un-focus lsxcommand (get out of the edit box)

command.name: CommandTime
command.description:
Format string that tells LSXCommand how you want your time and date to look.
(see lsxcommand.txt, section II.8 Clock Settings).

command.name: CommandClockDisappearsOnFocus
command.description: If you want the clock to automatically disappear when you click in LSXCommand, set this on. Otherwise, the clock will "pause" at the current time/date. This makes it easier for you to copy/paste the time and date into any app.

command.name: CommandScrollWinAmpTitle
command.description: If on, this setting takes WinAmp's scrolling title and displays it in LSXCommand. Note that WinAmp's scroll song title preference must be on for this to happen. A neat trick with this is to have both a clock and a WinAmp scroller. The WinAmp scroller will show when WinAmp is running. If not, the clock will show.

command.name: CommandWinAmpDisappearsOnFocus
command.description: Just like CommandClockDisappearsOnFocus, but for the WinAmp scrolling feature.

command.name: CommandMusicPlayer
command.description: This command enables LSXCommand to use the titles of other music players besides WinAmp. You should set it to the class name of the application you are looking for.

command.name: CommandNoTabMicroComplete
command.description:
Stops Tab-MicroCompletes from taking place. When you are typing in LSXCommand and get an autocompletion, you may want to automatically go on to the next word.
see also lsxcommand.txt, section II.5 Tab-MicroComplete and Context Menu Access

command.name: CommandTabFileComplete
command.description:
Enables the completion of file names by using the tab key.
see also lsxcommand.txt, section II.9 Tab File Completion

command.name: CommandNoAutoComplete
command.description: Turns *off* AutoComplete. Someone asked for it, so I coded it :).

command.name: CommandCommaDelimiter
command.description: Some Eurpoean countries use commas as decimal delimiters, so this changes decimals from periods to commas.

command.name: CommandRPNCalculator
command.description: Makes the calculator an RPN calculator. If you don't know what this is, don't use it! You'll only confuse yourself. Others call RPN "Postfix" notation. If you want to learn more, obtain a Hewlett-Packard RPN calculator (the 48/49 series are especially nice, IMO :).

command.name: CommandSearchEngineList
command.description:
The path to your engines.list - the list of search engines to use with LSXCommand.
see also lsxcommand.txt, section II.4 The engines.list File.

command.name: CommandSearchEngineBrowser
command.description: Path to the browser to be used with search engines. If not specified, LSXCommand uses the default browser on your system.

bang.name: FocusCommand
bang.description: Set focus to command (nice for binding to hotkeys).

bang.name: CommandRescanEngines
CommandClearHistory
bang.description: Clears both the history in memory *and* the history in $CommandHistoryFile$.

bang.name: CommandShowContextMenu
bang.description: Makes LSXCommand's Context Menu visible wherever the cursor is on the screen, regardless of LSXCommand's visibility.

bang.name: Command
bang.description: Now use the power of LSXCommand anywhere within Litestep! Shortcuts, wharf items, whatever that can run !bang commands outside of its own can now use LSXCommand.

bang.name: CommandShow
bang.description:
Just shows LSXCommand.
Note: It does *not* give LSXCommand focus. To do this, use !FocusCommand - this command gives focus to LSXCommand, and if it's not visible, it shows it also.

bang.name: CommandHide
bang.description: Just hides LSXCommand. Nothing really special.

bang.name: CommandBrowseFile
bang.description:
Brings up an Open Dialog Box to browse for a file for LSXCommand to open. It's just the same as typing in the file's name.
Note: You can send an argument to this !Bang command to specify the filter for the open box.
For instance, to see just Text Files, you might do this: !CommandBrowseFile All Text Files (*.txt, *.ini)|*.txt;*.ini

bang.name: CommandBrowseFolder
bang.description: Brings up a folder selection dialog. You can select a folder to browse to. There are no arguments for this !Bang command.

bang.name: CommandMove
bang.description:
Moves the LSXCommand window either to an absolute position, or by a delta along each axis. The horizontal and vertical values can be configured separately (you can mix absolute and delta values).
If the horizontal or vertical values are surrounded by parentheses, they are interpreted as absolute values. Otherwise, they are interpreted as +/- deltas along their respective axis.
If there is only one parameter, it is interpreted as a horizontal value.
!CommandMove 0 100 ; moves it 100 pixels down
When !CommandMove is called without parameters, it moves to the current mouse cursor position.
If !CommandMove is called with "home" as its parameter, it moves back to the original position it received from step.rc

bang.name: CommandToggleTimer
bang.description:
Toggles the current timer. If you use this, the WinAmp timer no longer takes precedence over the clock.
You have to call this !Bang again for the WinAmp scroller to appear.

bang.name: CommandSetText
bang.description:
This !Bang sets the text in LSXCommand to its arguments.
This makes for some really neat stuff (for instance, a shortcut that pops up LSXCommand with a question mark and a space already in it ready for an argument to search with).
Note: this !Bang command does not show LSXCommand if it is hidden.
Example: !SetText "?Altavista "

bang.name: CommandBoxHook
bang.description:
This is used with lsbox: *ModuleHook !CommandBoxHook
Please, check LsBox documentation
